channel.title: A gentlewoman and a scholar? on Monica Thieu
channel.description: Recent content in A gentlewoman and a scholar? on Monica Thieu

item.title: CoVID19: soothing anxiety with data, sort of
item.description: US-specific stuff Re-centering by date of first confirmed positive test US-specific stuff corona %>% filter(type == "confirmed", Country.Region == "US", !is.na(State.Abb)) %>% ggplot(aes(x = date, y = cases, color = State.Abb)) + geom_line() + # scale_y_log10() + theme_bw() Re-centering by date of first confirmed positive test corona %>% filter(type == "confirmed") %>% mutate(Sub.Region = if_else(!is.na(Province.State), paste(Country.Region, Province.State), Country.Region)) %>% arrange(date) %>% group_by(Sub.Region) %>% mutate(cumul_cases = cumsum(cases)) %>% filter(cumul_cases > 0) %>% mutate(days_since_first_case = 0:(n()-1)) %>% nest(days = -Sub.

item.title: Setting up this website

item.title: Hierarchical bootstrapping
item.description: What’s bootstrapping again? Basic tidy bootstrapping Multilevel data: a real cluster-f Honoring the structure of the data: it matters! There’s a lot of things to be anxious about lately. One of the more harmless questions I worry about is–am I estimating the standard error of my statistics incorrectly? Bootstrapping my standard errors is a great way to tackle that anxiety. However, bootstrapping can get a bit more complex as data take on a more complex structure (for example, multilevel structure), and the way that we resample our data can have big impacts on the variance of the resulting distributions.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown Including Plots R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.

item.title: About me
item.description: Where I’m at. Some of my code. Talk to me. A snapshot of my CV. Awards and honors Teaching experience Publications and presentations Where I’m at. I’m currently a PhD student in Dr. Kevin Ochsner’s Social Cognitive & Affective Neuroscience Lab at Columbia University, where I began in fall 2017. While I’m not working on research (and often while I am), I’m probably drinking from a very large cup of tea.

item.title: Game shows
item.description: (2012) Jeopardy! College Championship (2013) Jeopardy! Tournament of Champions (2016) 500 Questions, season 2 (2019) Jeopardy! All-Star Games Photos (poorly organized, sorry!) First things first… Buy a Team Ken shirt or other swag here to represent/embarrass Ken Jennings, the GOAT. All profits donated to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network in honor of Alex Trebek. When I was little, instead of doing normal kid things, I would read piles upon piles of nonfiction books about history and science.

item.title: Research
item.description: Research tools Recruiting online participants Running behavioral tasks online Active projects Individual differences in age perception Measurement of emotion self-reporting Previous projects Attention, memory, and media multitasking Healthy aging and associative memory Research tools Recruiting online participants I recently started using prolific.co, a researcher-friendly website for online behavioral study recruitment that’s kind both to researchers and to participants. All my contacts with participants have been pleasant, and the Prolific support staff are so responsive and helpful.
